repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This allows the `vim.treesitter.query` module once again to be `require`d in fast API events.

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

Fixes #35071 (I think, cc @misanthropicbit to confirm? and maybe help with a test case if possible)

comment_regular_data.body:
Awesome! Thanks @ribru17 ðŸ™‚ LGTM.

I don't have a good test case for this unfortunately but I managed to get it to somewhat consistently trigger on an old commit on a PR branch so I'll try to check that commit out and patch my local neovim version (0.11.3).

> I'm not really sure why autocmd creation isn't allowed in fast.

since CI is failing, maybe try this patch:

```diff
diff --git a/src/nvim/api/autocmd.c b/src/nvim/api/autocmd.c
index f215b0c1c860..554f75498f6a 100644
--- a/src/nvim/api/autocmd.c
+++ b/src/nvim/api/autocmd.c
@@ -393,6 +393,7 @@ cleanup:
 Integer nvim_create_autocmd(uint64_t channel_id, Object event, Dict(create_autocmd) *opts,
                             Arena *arena, Error *err)
   FUNC_API_SINCE(9)
+  FUNC_API_FAST
 {
   int64_t autocmd_id = -1;
   char *desc = NULL;
```
There are probably many more API functions (and "eval" vimscript functions) that could be marked "fast". That's an ongoing goal.

Is it the case that any api functions which don't defer to another event loop iteration can be marked as fast? And if so is it easy to tell which ones defer (or don't), maybe like a grep for `schedule...()`?

More "fast" functions can lead to more segfaults, as they can be invoked in `os_breakcheck()` calls of any random code path. And there seem to be no documented criteria on what functions should (or can) be "fast".
For my own learning, why would a function segfault when invoked in an `os_breakcheck()` call but not when invoked otherwise?

#23012 is an example: some code is invoked recursively when it isn't designed to be. Some possible examples (not entirely sure): regexp matching, wildcard expansion, expression evaluation.

Another kind of segfault that may happen is that a function called inside `os_breakcheck()` causes some state changes that the calling code path isn't expecting.

There may indeed be a potential problem with marking `nvim_create_autocmd` as "fast". `aucmd_next()` calls `match_file_pat()`, which does regexp matching and may call `os_breakcheck()`. If an autocommand is added there, `acs->items[]` may be reallocated, causing `ac` and `ap` to point to freed memory.

Thanks for those notes @zeertzjq !  I started a `:help dev-api-fast` in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35138 .

> `aucmd_next()` calls `match_file_pat()`, which does regexp matching and may call `os_breakcheck()`. If an autocommand is added there, `acs->items[]` may be reallocated, causing `ac` and `ap` to point to freed memory.

Can `nvim_create_autocmd` set a global "no breakcheck" flag? Similar to `EW_NOBREAK`, but global. This should be safe because `nvim_create_autocmd` is not something that can get "stuck" (unless someone defines a crazy autocmd pattern).
It's not breakcheck happening inside `nvim_create_autocmd`. It's `nvim_create_autocmd` happening inside breakcheck.

ðŸ˜‚ ok, can `aucmd_next` set a "no breakcheck" flag?

We need to start building ideas and patterns around this.

Just chiming in with an update on the `vim.schedule` solution itself. I tested this out with a local patch of 0.11.3 as mentioned above and the changes makes my tests  pass without issues. Removing the patch gives me the error again.

What's the point of breakcheck in `aucmd_next`? As far as I can tell, it's just so the user can interrupt with `<Ctrl-C>` in the case the loop hangs for what ever reason. I think in these situations, we probably don't want Lua fast events to be processed? In other words, `nvim_create_autocmd` should never be able to become recursive.

Though I don't doubt I've probably misunderstood something here.

`os_breakcheck()` is also done in regexp matching, not just directly in `aucmd_next()`.

And, again, there is nothing recursive going on here.
Does that address my point? Again, I'm not sure we should be calling Lua/luv fast events during a regexp breakcheck. Do we really need to combine Lua/luv fast events with Ctrl-C checking?

Also could we change `match_file_pat()` to be optionally run with the `RE_NOBREAK` flag. That will prevent the breakchecks from regexp. We then should consider removing `line_breakcheck()` in `aucmd_next()`.

Ctrl-C checking won't be possible without RPC `nvim_input` fast events. If `nvim_create_autocmd` becomes "fast", it's also a fast event over RPC.

> Also could we change `match_file_pat()` to be optionally run with the `RE_NOBREAK` flag. That will prevent the breakchecks from regexp. We then should consider removing `line_breakcheck()` in `aucmd_next()`.

I thought about the first part too. Removing the `line_breakcheck()` isn't necessary as `ap` and `ac` aren't used after that.

labels.description: issue needs attention from an expert, or PR proposes significant changes to architecture or API
labels.name: needs:discussion

title: feat(api): mark nvim_create_autocmd as |api-fast|
